content.description: A scientist performed an experiment to test the ability of chloroplasts to produce <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math> in the dark. The scientist maintained chloroplasts under dark conditions and placed them first in a <math alttext="p H 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>4</mtext></math> solution for <math alttext="15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn></math> seconds and then in a <math alttext="p H 8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>8</mtext></math> solution containing <math alttext="A D P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ADP</mi></math> and <math alttext="P sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></math> (inorganic phosphate). Under these conditions, the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of the stroma increased to <math alttext="8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn></math>, the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of the thylakoid space remained at <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, and the chloroplasts produced <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math>.
content.question: Which of the following best explains how the difference in <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> between the stroma and the thylakoid space enabled the chloroplasts to produce <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math> in the dark?

choices.label: The difference in <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> created a proton gradient that enabled protons to pass through <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math> synthase, activating it to produce <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math>.

The difference in <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> enabled complexes of protons and <math alttext="A D P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ADP</mi></math> in the thylakoid space to move through <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math> synthase to the stroma, producing <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math>.

The difference in <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> stimulated the electron flow needed to pump protons into the stroma and induce <math alttext="P sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="A D P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ADP</mi></math> to bond and form <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math>.

The difference in <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> caused the photosystems to release high energy electrons that provided enough energy for <math alttext="A D P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ADP</mi></math> and <math alttext="P sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></math> to bond and form <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math>.
